227799331.name: February Meetup
227799331.description:
This month we have two speakers talking at NottsJS.


David Wood - Introduction to TypeScript

Discover what TypeScript is, how it's useful, and how to get started using the language in new and existing projects.


Chris Kemp - Keep your codebase clean

Understanding source control is a requirement in modern software development, so let's get back to basics. Talk through the history and fundamentals, and then move on to how keeping a clean git history helps you out as a business, with practical examples from my own personal experience.

227799340.name: April Meetup
227799340.description:
Following the success of the first NottsJS, where we kicked off with a nodeschool, we’re back, and very excited to announce that we’re running another nodeschool.


This workshop themed event aims to give you hands-on experience with new technologies and help you take home new skills so don’t forget to bring your laptop!


Don’t panic! If you're new to coding and have never written a line of code before, that’s OK! You will be made to feel welcome as we cater for all skill levels and we will be delighted to have you onboard! If you’re a seasoned pro, let us know! We need help with mentoring.


We are really excited to welcome our guest host Michele Capra, who will be joining us from Italy to share his knowledge and expertise on Seneca. He's a Software Engineer with a passion for clean code and as a contributor to Node.js really understands the language.

Michele is the author of the "Seneca in Practice", the workshop we will be presenting.

Afterwards we go round the corner to the Keans Head for more JavaScript socialising.

Want to know more about our speaker? Visit his website at

http://about.me/mik

Ask questions or to talk to our friendly community at:


https://gitter.im/nottsjs/discuss

227799344.name: May Meetup
227799344.description:
The Web as a Creative Medium

Have a fireside chat with Greg Tatum about how to use the web as a creative medium. Learn how to quickly iterate on ideas in a flexible space, and instantly share your work with the globe at large. Explore the underlying technologies like 2d canvas, WebGL, and SVG, plus the frameworks that make it easy to be productive.

Greg Tatum 

(Greg will be voiping in from America, we will have a mic on hand for Q and A)

React and Redux from the Trenches


Lessons learned from working with React and Redux for the past 6 months to create an asynchronous, isomorphic, server-side rendered SPA complete with RESTful API powered by Python/Django.

Essentially: dos, don'ts, gotchas, best practice approaches, red herrings, false starts, and evolving practices.

Technologies include webpack, Express, react-router, redux-simple-router, CSS Modules, react-cookie, Mocha/Chai, Babel, ES2015/2016, Immutable, cheerio, etc.

Andrew J. Baker and Kristian Roebuck

After

Afterwards we go round the corner to the Keans Head for more JavaScript socialising.

Contact


Ask questions or to talk to our friendly community at:

https://gitter.im/nottsjs/discuss

Find us on twitter:  @nottsjs
227799344.how_to_find_us: On Stoney street between the cemetery, ring the buzzer someone will let you in.

227799348.name: June Meetup - Command Unity
227799348.description:
Join us, as father and son attempt to rule the universe.

Leif Kemp will be talking about using JavaScript in Unity, and be giving a live coding demo where he builds a world you can walk through and shows you how to interact with it through JavaScript.

Chris Kemp will be talking about applications being more than just CRUD operations, and what the wider impact to your business is.  Also covering some basic concepts such as CQS, CQRS & Event Sourcing with an example in Redux.
227799348.how_to_find_us: Next door to St. Mary's Church in Nottingham

230755582.name: July meetup
230755582.description:
Playing with WebRTC


WebRTC is useful tech... but who cares about useful? Let's do something fun!

Let's take a look at WebRTC. It will be weird. Hopefully it will be fun. You might even learn something.

Mark Goodwin is a security expert for Mozilla


Bring a laptop, we will have a hacking session.


After

Afterwards we go round the corner to the Keans Head for more JavaScript socialising.

Contact

Ask questions or to talk to our friendly community at:

https://gitter.im/nottsjs/discuss

Find us on twitter: 

@nottsjs

232108963.name: August meetup
232108963.description:
Talks


Exploring using the Web Audio API to allow people to hear charts and plots
by matatk


Charts and plots are engaging and widely used on the web, but present barriers to people with vision impairments, as well as those who cannot use a mouse, or are using small devices.

A lot of research has been done into using sound as a means of communicating information to people and the benefits this can bring to people in various situations. Now that the Web Audio API is well-supported, some really interesting stuff is being done with it, and this talk will show you how it's an ideal way to make charts and plots more accessible.


Server-Side Rendering of React on Java 8 Nashorn with Spring Boot
by ruth-connect

How do you use the Nashorn JS engine on Java 8 to perform server-side rendering React on Spring Boot? Come along to find out!


This talk will cover the Nashorn JS engine, including the ability to execute JS code on the server-side from within a Java application (and even have the JS code call Java code); how to integrate the Nashorn JS engine within the view layer of a Spring web application; and how to use Nashorn to render the initial state of a React application on the server.

After

Afterwards we'll head around the corner to Keans Head for more JavaScript socialising.

Contact

Ask questions or to talk to our friendly community at:

https://gitter.im/nottsjs/discuss


Find us on twitter:

@nottsjs

232108994.name: September meetup
232108994.description:
Talks

Realtime Apps with Node.js and RethinkDB
by Matt Collins

In today's online world, user experience is key. Users expect slick interfaces that are intuitive, informative and engaging. More and more, building apps that update the user in Realtime are becoming an essential part of this experience - and we can see this every day with things like Google Docs, Facebook Notifications, Slack and BBC Live Text.

RethinkDB is a fully featured, opensource, NoSQL database designed to make developing for the Realtime Web easy. We'll talk about changefeeds, clustering and how combining with Node.js can help you avoid some of the pitfalls of building rich, engaging, Realtime Apps to scale and across multiple platforms.

By the end of this talk you'll be ready to go back and create your first Realtime App with RethinkDB and Node.js.

After

Afterwards we'll head around the corner to Keans Head for more JavaScript socialising.

Contact

Ask questions or to talk to our friendly community on Gitter!

Find us on twitter: @nottsjs

233944144.name: October meetup
233944144.description:
Talks

Exploring Progressive Web Apps
by Dan Shea

Web apps can be pretty cool, but we could be making them even cooler. Browsers are levelling up by adding functionality to enable a user experience akin to using a native mobile application.

Enter the new buzz-phrase of the moment… Progressive Web Apps!

This talk aims to share knowledge gained from Dan's time at FullStack 2016 conference, and the lessons learned from implementing the features into real web applications. The goal is to provide more than just a high level overview; you should be able to walk away confident that you can implement these features into your own web apps straight away.

You'll find out why you should care, what's available, see a demo and see what features are offered in browsers.


After


Afterwards we'll head around the corner to Keans Head for more JavaScript socialising.

Contact

Ask questions or to talk to our friendly community on Gitter!

Find us on twitter: @nottsjs
233944144.how_to_find_us: Down the road from Annie's Burger Shack

233944192.name: November meetup
233944192.description:
NottsJS do the TopGear "Cool Wall" for Web Technologies + Workshops

With something that is approaching attention deficit disorder there's new JavaScript frameworks emerging weekly. Even the godfather of modern JS development, jQuery, has been knocked from it's perch and is considered passé.

So what do we do now? How do we leverage the good tech, while avoiding the cargo cults?

This month we're going for something completely new. Enter The Cool Wall. A segment that will prove so popular that Jeremy Clarkson will invent Time Travel to steal it from us and make into a popular segment on Top Gear.

This month's session will be a group discussion piece where we talk about the state of modern JavaScript development and our place in this world.

233944267.name: #NottTechParty - The Nottingham Tech Community Christmas Party
233944267.description:
Nottingham's biggest and brightest tech events are coming together to celebrate the stellar growth of the community by throwing another awesome Christmas party.

We're taking over the National Videogame Arcade, with full access to all the games and exhibits, an organised games tournament with pizza and drinks.

Tickets are just £5! The price of your ticket includes full access to the National Videogame Arcade, the games tournament and pizza.

First tickets released this Friday 11th November at midday - Buy your ticket now!

<a href="http://www.technottingham.com/events/2016/12/8/notttechparty-the-nottingham-tech-community-christmas-party-2016"></a>

Joining on Meetup does not count as buying a ticket!

236607131.name: January 2017 Meetup
236607131.description:
Talks

Elm
by Will White

Elm is a domain-specific, purely functional programming language used for declaratively creating client-side web apps which compile to JavaScript.

In this talk you'll be shown The Elm Architecture, a nestable pattern for building applications, and Elm's full type inference system that helps prevent users from running into errors.

We'll look at how Elm handles HTTP requests and websockets, how it handles uncertainty, the use of partial function application for reusable views, interaction with JS libraries, and how data immutability gives you undo/redo for only a few lines of code.


After 

Afterwards we'll head around the corner to Keans Head for more JavaScript socialising.

Contact

Ask questions or to talk to our friendly community on Gitter!

Find us on twitter: @nottsjs

236607141.name: February 2017 Meetup - We ♥ JS
236607141.description:
It's the time of year to love what you do. To give it some extra time, care and attention, keeping it happily ticking over for another year.

The difference is, we don't have to buy it a romantic meal or get an awkward pampering at a health spa. We don't have to throw rose petals over the desk and lie in wait clutching a thorny flower between our teeth. And we definitely don't have to waste trees by buying it a card with a heart on the front.

What we love is JavaScript. Whether it be in the browser or on the server, frontend or backend, React or Inferno - whatever takes your fancy, we're here to appreciate it with you!

In this session we will discuss what we truly love about JavaScript in fast-paced quick-chair-swapping-one-on-one chats ("speed teching"), gathering our thoughts and opinions together to create our very own list of what we love about JavaScript. This list will help us get to know each other better by what, how and why we do what we do.

We'll save this list until the end of the year for the next JS Cool Wall event, and hope to see how our love changes over the following 10 months.

So please join us in a loving and cherishing NottsJS!

236607150.name: March 2017 - Hands On with React
236607150.description:
This will be your opportunity to create a real-life website using React.

We don't always get the opportunity to use the latest new technologies in our day-to-day jobs, and when we do get chance to pick up something we do so in our spare time and don't have a real problem that we're trying to solve.

This session will address that, by introducing the audience to React and then having members of the group contribute to the new NottsJS website.

What will I get out of this?

• Use React to:

• Build a Website.

• Use web components.


• Use 3rd party styling packages.


• Use webpack to hot load changes.


• Load data using Async processing of data.


• Contributing to an Open Source project.

236607159.name: April 2017 - Firefox Containers, isolating the web whilst hacking web extensions
236607159.description:
Presenting Jonathan Kingston with his talk and workshop: "Firefox Containers, isolating the web whilst hacking web extensions".

Bring your laptops with a copy of Firefox Nightly installed as we will hack away at building your own extensions using bleeding edge features.

Firefox Containers tabs are an experimental platform feature for tab management and isolating browsing to solve security and privacy issues.

With the recent launch of containers to test pilot, I'm going to walk through how they are built. Web Extensions are the new cross browser way of adding features to the browser built entirely from JavaScript and other web technologies. New web extension features were added to Firefox for building our containers experiment that you can use today.


I will cover the basics of building extensions so we can have half the evening on hacking and making extensions.

Image credit: Carolyn Jaeger

speaker.name: Jonathan Kingston
speaker.intro: Jonathan is a Front End security developer working on Firefox for Mozilla

239020788.name: May 2017 - Chat Bots
239020788.description:
Join us with our guest speaker Manthan Dave with his talk: "Up and running with chat bots: A journey from being a noob to being awesome"

The chat bot revolution is upon us and every developer wants to build one. This workshop will take them on an epic journey starting from basics and writing a simple chat bot, all the way to learning advanced concepts.

Ever wondered what goes behind a good chat bot? Do you want to build one? Well this workshop is for you!

Complexity can be diffused as soon as you peek behind the curtain. A chat bot, like a website might look complex from the outside, but the reality is different.

This workshop will be divided into three sections. The first section will cover the basic anatomy of a chat bot. Next, we'll work together to build a chat bot. We'll start simple with a chat bot that'll tell us knock knock and chuck norris jokes. Towards the end of the workshop, we'll go over some advanced concepts that can help us scale our chat bot to have more features.

So come! Join us on an awesome journey to talkify our bots!
